For this pilot's widow, Sarkozy's Libyan funding case is personal
Subhead: The 1989 bombing of UTA Flight 772, ordered by the Libyan regime of Muammar Gaddafi, robbed Maryvone Raveneau of her husband. As a plaintiff in the trial of Nicolas Sarkozy, who is accused of having struck a deal with Gaddafi, she has been disappointed by the media battle waged by the former French president and his supporters.

In India, a fire at a popular Goa nightclub kills at least 23
Subhead: The deadly blaze broke out around midnight at a club in Arpora, in North Goa district. Officials will conduct fire safety audits at similar venues to prevent similar incidents from occurring.

Title: Asma Mhalla, political scientist: 'Peter Thiel embeds AI in a worldview where conflict and the state of emergency become virtues'
Subhead: As American tech billionaire Peter Thiel criticizes a global order that stifles progress, he and other Silicon Valley players are looking to replace it with a technological totalitarianism that Europe must reject, argues researcher Asma Mhalla.

Title: When Christmas presents are secondhand: 'My sisters looked at me strangely'
Subhead: Far from consumerist extravaganzas like 'Black Friday' or 'Cyber Monday,' some people in France prefer to turn to secondhand and recycled goods for their holiday shopping. Juggling the risks of technical failure and the fear of being seen as 'cheapskates,' they share their experiences.

Title: 100 years of the photobooth: Meet the people keeping them alive
Subhead: Created in New York in 1925, the analog photobooth has come close to extinction over the years. Two passionate restorers, Eddy Bourgeois and Virginie Voisneau, are helping keep the vintage booth alive in France and beyond.
